dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey, B, did you see the latest, uh, US company rankings? Guess who's at the very top this year?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey, B, did you see the latest, uh, U S company rankings? Guess who's at the very top this year?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, wow, um, is it Apple again? Or like, Amazon maybe? They're always so big.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, wow, um, is it Apple again? Or like, Amazon maybe? They're always so big.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Nope! JPMorgan Chase! They actually, like, totally leapfrogged Apple and Berkshire Hathaway.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Nope! J P Morgan Chase! They actually, like, totally leapfrogged Apple and Berkshire Hathaway.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The banking giant, which boasted $2.7 trillion in assets as of the 12 months ending on April 18, 2019, overtook Apple and Berkshire Hathaway to claim the top spot on the list.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [surprised] No way! Really? That's kinda wild. So, banks are really dominating then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No way! Really? That's kinda wild. So, banks are really dominating then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, kind of. I mean, the top five are JPMorgan, Bank of America, Apple, Wells Fargo, and Exxon Mobil.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, kind of. I mean, the top five are J P Morgan, Bank of America, Apple, Wells Fargo, and Exxon Mobil.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bank of America, Apple, Wells Fargo and Exxon Mobil round out the top five.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So Apple's still up there, but not number one. I thought they were, um, like, the most profitable, globally?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So Apple's still up there, but not number one. I thought they were, um, like, the most profitable, globally?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: They *are* still the most profitable globally, pulling in almost sixty billion last year! And still the largest by market cap in the US.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They are still the most profitable globally, pulling in almost sixty billion last year! And still the largest by market cap in the U S.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple ranks third on the U.S. list in 2019, though it remains the most profitable public company in the world, pulling in nearly $60 billion last year. Apple is also the largest U.S. company by market capitalization, clocking in at about $927 billion at the end of the same period.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, right. So, what happened to Berkshire Hathaway then? I thought they were always, like, top three.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, right. So, what happened to Berkshire Hathaway then? I thought they were always, like, top three.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Oh, they actually fell eleven spots! All the way down to twelfth because of that big Kraft Heinz write-down.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, they actually fell eleven spots! All the way down to twelfth because of that big Kraft Heinz write-down.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Notably, Berkshire Hathaway has fallen 11 spots since last year, when it tied with Apple for the number one spot. Warren Buffet's storied holding company ranks 12th this year thanks to a major writedown (courtesy of its holding Kraft Heinz) in the fourth quarter of 2018.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, I remember hearing about that. And Citigroup? Didn't they have a rough patch?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, I remember hearing about that. And Citigroup? Didn't they have a rough patch?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Citigroup actually rocketed from 190 last year, uh, all the way up to number seven! Crazy jump.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Citigroup actually rocketed from one hundred ninety last year, uh, all the way up to number seven! Crazy jump.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Citigroup, on the other hand, ranked 190 on an extended list in 2018 thanks to losses related to assets overseas, rocketed back up to number 7.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That *is* a huge jump! Kinda makes you wonder about the market overall though, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That is a huge jump! Kinda makes you wonder about the market overall though, you know?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. I mean, 2018 was super volatile, especially December. Markets rebounded a bit, but now with these trade war tensions...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. I mean, twenty eighteen was super volatile, especially December. Markets rebounded a bit, but now with these trade war tensions...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: U.S. stocks had a tumultuous year in 2018, especially during the final month of the year when the S&P 500 swung 1,000 points in a single trading day. Markets rebounded during the first quarter of 2019, but the escalation of trade war tensions between the United States and China in recent weeks have investors wondering if that volatility and trade uncertainty, sure to have an enormous impact on American companies, is the new normal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's just, like, what's next? Is this volatility and, um, uncertainty the new normal, do you think?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's just, like, what's next? Is this volatility and, um, uncertainty the new normal, do you think?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It certainly feels like investors are, uh, wondering the exact same thing. It's a tricky time.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It certainly feels like investors are, uh, wondering the exact same thing. It's a tricky time.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...investors wondering if that volatility and trade uncertainty, sure to have an enormous impact on American companies, is the new normal.
